review_title: A+ Flashlight. Excellent in Every Way
reviews:
I purchased the MT2A 2015 Edition about a year ago, and have carried and used it every day in my back left pocket. I walk a lot, commute on a bike, and work in building maintenance. I frequently use it in construction or repair situations. Not once have I had a single issue with the light. Here are the things I like most about it:

1. Operation Interface -- I can operate the light in the dark with one hand, accessing all of the different modes. It is impossible to accidentally actuate the mode selector, as in the models featuring side-buttons. The turbo mode is always instantly accessible via the turning flashlight head--this allows me to use it as a self-defense light and a utility light. (If you're unfamiliar with the MT2A's operation, a YouTube video is the best way to see how it works).

(I hate side-button operation because it is easily to accidentally change modes, which would be catastrophic in a tactical situation. It is also difficult to operate those lights quickly in the dark or in any tactical situation.)

2. Mode selection -- the modes are well-selected to balance runtime and brightness. Turbo mode is bright enough to disable an attacker at night, and somehow will still operate for two whole hours. As an emergency light, low mode is bright enough to be useful while still providing an impressively long runtime of 50 hours. I keep mine on medium and replace the batteries weekly. They never even come close to running dry.

3. Beam spread -- before this light, I was using a ThruNite Archer 2A V3. I loved the orange peel beam spread, which offered a complete gradient. At first, the tighter beam of the MT2A was difficult to adjust to. However, I grew to prefer it as it provides better throw and uses the available lumens more efficiently. The secondary beam area (spill) is still bright enough to be useful.

4. Durability. The MT2A is incredibly tough. Again, this opens the possibility of using it as a weapon (especially with the striker bezel--nice touch!). But more, I simply appreciate the security of expecting my light not to fail.

5. Price -- The MT2A is not expensive, compared to other comparable options.

6. Battery type -- though Li-Ion batteries are better-performing, I have dozens of eneloop AA cells for photography usage. I also like knowing that in a pinch, I could throw a standard alkaline or lithium cell in there in an emergency. I keep Energizer lithiums on hand just in case.

Here are my two complaints:

1. The user-selectable function, which cycles the light's mode every time the button is pressed, allows too much time (three seconds) after each button press to re-press the button and change the mode. In other words, it is too easy to accidentally change to a different mode when all you wanted to do was cycle the light on and off. One second of time would be sufficient.

This would be a deal-breaker, except that the "Turbo" mode is always instantly accessible by tightening the flashlight head. This way, in "turbo" mode, I can clear a room or perform other tactical tasks, which often require switching the flashlight off and on quickly, using the temporary-on function of the switch.

2. The beam is quite cool-colored. I like the option of a high-CRI beam, even if it must be a few lumens dimmer. (My ThruNite beam was very pleasant to use, although it may have even been too warm-colored).

I don't think there is a better AA flashlight out there, especially at this price point. AA lights will be relevant as long as that battery type remains widely used. Keep up the great work, Nitecore!

reviews:

review_title: This light has a propensity to choke itself to death on its own batteries.
reviews:
I loved this flashlight initially. It was solidly built, very bright, light weight, and worked well. I work as an investigator, so this light was a part of my equipment that saw regular use (though not HARD use). The problem was that after about 6 months or so of ownership, it didn't turn on one day (no indication that the batteries were dying or anything-- just here today, gone tomorrow). So I opened it up to change the batteries, and discovered that both of them had exploded and leaked corrosive acid crap all over the inside of my light. Furthermore, the batteries had swelled to the point where I couldn't extract them-- rendering the light useless.

I figured that this was my fault: I hadn't been vigilant in keeping the batteries checked and maintained. And because I liked this light so much, I ordered a second one, promising myself that I'd be much more conscientious of the replacement. Well low and behold, after approximately 4 months, the SAME EXACT thing happened. I had been keeping a close eye on the light, the batteries were not old, and were in working order, and the flashlight did not sit in some dank cellar-- it saw light use almost daily.

So long story short, if you'd like a "survival light" that'll last you about 4 months into the zombie apocalypse before it kills itself, choking to death on its own batteries, I'd highly recommend this. Me personally, I think I'll be going back to the beastly old mag-lights that could survive anything.

review_title: Great for the daily carry flashlight.
reviews:
I really like this flashlight. It's small enough to carry around, but not too small that you lose it. I've experimented with various flashlights, and finally settled on this one.
The beam is pretty even. There's a definite center ring where the light is brightest, but beyond the center ring the light doesn't just drop off, it gets gradually less bright. You cannot focus the beam, but with the way the beam is focused by default, I'm pretty happy with it. I'll try and add some pictures on the beam focus with this review.
Modes are fun to play with on a flashlight, but usually all I need is a bright beam, so I'm not huge on multiple functions. I especially don't like it when you have one button to cycle through the different modes. It's rather annoying to have to cycle through the buttons to get to the mode I need. That said, having a couple different brightness levels can be nice. If you have a light that is too bright looking into a hole you can't see anything. Enter Turbo Mode! With Turbo Mode no matter where you're at in the modes, if you need a steady light, just turn the head to the left and you've got it! Turbo Mode does not lack for brightness either! If you need something other than a steady light, you probably can take the time to cycle through your options.
The flashlight is easy to grab and hold. It fits nicely in your hand. The button is easy to press, but protected on two sides to help keep it from being turned on accidentally. It's not too fat, or too long for every day carry - and this light goes just about everywhere I go!
Battery: Two AA batteries to me is preferable to other batteries. You can find AAs pretty much anywhere for a decent price, and it doesn't hurt the size of the flashlight.
The Holster is pretty nice, though if you use it, don't pull the flap down too much or the end of the flashlight will eat through the case.

review_title: Top of the line replacement for a Mini-Maglite
reviews: I looked long and hard for a good replacement for a Mini-Maglite, and this is definitely it. I have a 2 pouch holster (one for a multi-tool, one for the Maglite) that I really like, so I needed something that was very close the the same dimensions for a good fit. My problem was that the Mini-Maglite twists the head to turn it on (annoyingly needing two hands to do so), and sometimes friction in the pouch would turn it on without me knowing, leaving it dead when I needed it. Most other push-button flashlights have an unprotected button, so sometimes this unwanted activation occurs with them too. This Nitecore is expensive, but the CREE LED bulb is the reason. If you want a very bright LED flashlight CREE bulbs are the only way to go until the next technology leap occurs, so you'll be paying more for any flashlight so equipped. The housing around the push-button solves any unwanted activation, it is very bright, and is it almost exactly the size of a Mini-Maglite. It comes with it's own holster, a spare set of "O" rings to keep it watertight, a wrist strap, and the pocket clip is removable if not needed. It does have the extra functions that many of the latest crop of bright flashlights have (hi-med-lo beam, SOS, strobe), but getting them going is a two handed head twist that I doubt I will use, and suspect others won't either. It will always go with hi-beam (they call it "Turbo"mode") first, and if not selecting any other function, will reduce power after 3 minutes as an energy saving function. Smart. This is a top of the line mini- flashlight and it completely met all of my requirements. I would say it is worth the money. I am retired military/law enforcement, and I would take the Nitecore with me on mission every time -- two of them, just to be sure).

review_title: I would say this light is better overall. I can assure you that the lumen
reviews: If anyone's wants to compare this to the Nitecore MT21A, I would say this light is better overall. I can assure you that the lumen, peak intensity, and beam distance ratings do not tell you the full story. This light is a wonderful AA EDC light. Love the adjustable pocket clip and the anti-roll bezel. The throw on the light is decent; you can get enough light to identify obj/ ppl at 80-90 yards. This light does not throw as far as the MT21A, but realistically this light throws only 30-40 yards shorter. This light's wider beam profile is actually closer to a throw beam than a flood beam. The light is very comfortable to carry and light weight. At 345 lumens, the light is blinding at an range under 10-20 yards. The biggest down side I see is that the run time on turbo isn't going to be longer than 20mins b/c of overheating. If your using rechargeable batteries, be careful since this light does not have low voltage warnings.

I gave this a 4 star and not a 5 is because of how it selects from turbo - to the user define mode - is just a twist of a head cap. If you twist the head cap enough it comes off and the batteries can come out. The batteries are accessible through the bottom cap (where the button is located too). By all means the headcap is not loose at ALL when you select to user define mode and it has a nice friction to it when you twist. But if the headcap couldn't come all the way off or if it was just a click when we/ I turned the head to select modes, i think it would ideal. But that's just my opinion in selecting modes.

reviews:
If you need sustained light levels of over 300 lumens, do not buy this light.

If you only need the occasional brightness of 300+ lumens, this this will work.

On AA Sony Stamina Plus, starting in turbo, the light lasted about 45 minutes. With Eneloop Pro is lasted around 1.5 hours starting on turbo.
Even on alkaline batteries, if you aren't using turbo all the time, it will last a good while.

Decent spread of light levels at the different modes. Don't know why everyone feels the need to include a strobe, especially when you have momentary on; but, it's there for ya!

Included holster actually works well and is sized correctly for the MT2A. Drop tested it from waist high several times, no flicker. Dropped it in a sink of water for about 1 min. No leaks, bubbles, flickering. Pocket clip is there, though the positioning is not great.

If you need longer times of sustained high output, you can check out the Mini-Mag Pro or Pro+. Pro+ has a high of 245lumens and one lower mode. Lasts longer on high, but less output and only 2 modes (high mode only on Pro).

review_title: Went kaput after exactly a month
reviews:
Was great while it lasted ... for exactly one month. I didn't drop it or get it wet or anything - unlike a lot of folks, I actually take care of my gear. One day, it just stopped working entirely. Like a fool, I'd already tossed the box and everything else, so no warranty return option for me. Soooooo, now I'm back to using my trusty little $5 Chinese LED AA-battery light again - hasn't failed me yet in almost 4 years. This Nitecore light, though, didn't even make it past 30 days.

Swapped in several different brands of batteries, but to no avail. Totally a bummer. Up until then, however, it was an awesome little light that I used quite a bit at work. Plenty bright when you want it, or just the right amount of light if you use the lower-power setting, and it didn't chew through batteries like candy. The bonus holster it came with is okay, I suppose, but I never needed it, so it just went into a box in the closet. The pocket clip isn't terrible, but it would be a lot better if it was stronger. Had the light work itself upward and unclip itself on several occasions just from crouching or sitting down and then standing up again, but fortunately it just fell down inside of my pocket instead of dropping out entirely.

Took a chance by going with this brand that I'd never heard of before, and I guess I'll chalk this one up as a learning experience. If you're going to spend more than ten bucks on an LED light, I guess it's best to go with a known name brand.
